none: Box 1 Folder 20 J. R. Cole Papers

body.value:
Checking and Transcriptions Reproductions against Originals

1. Originals in the James Reid Cole File

2. Reproductions and Transcriptions in Supplement to First First Five Administrations of Texas A. and M. College James Reid
Cole, 1879-1885

Item 1: The Weekly Brazas(?) Pil0t(?)

Commencement Edition, June 27, 1883
Contents: Riport of the Acting President
to Hon J.D. Thomas, President of the
Board of Directors, June 1883, on
the State of the College

Item 2: Fragment from James Reid
Cole's Diary, 1882-1883, on College
conditions, cadets, officers, teachers,
telephones, chapel exercises(?), room(?) fights
in College Mess Hall

Analyzing the Transcription Task

I’m currently focused on the initial analysis of this transcription request. The primary goal is clearly to render handwritten text into a digital format. The source being a handwritten note on lined paper adds certain complexities that I must account for, such as preserving line breaks and formatting.

Defining Transcription Goals

My current focus is defining the transcription goals in more detail. I’m prioritizing accuracy, completeness (including marginalia), and fidelity to the original structure. I’ve broken this down into specific sub-goals, such as accurate handwriting interpretation, preserving line breaks, and using markdown appropriately. I’ve also established guidelines for handling unclear text.

Examining Textual Changes

I’m now deeply analyzing the changes made to the phrase. The original intent seems to have been “Checking Transcriptions against Originals.” The writer then crossed out “Transcriptions” and inserted “Reproductions” above it. There’s a subtle insertion marker, but the core change is replacing one noun with another. This suggests a shift in the nature of what’s being checked, from transcribed text to potentially reproduced content. I’m focusing on why this change occurred.

Dissecting Visual Layout

The visual layout of the phrase is now under intense scrutiny. I’m focusing on the precise positioning of each word and alteration. The minuscule “and” between “Reproductions” and the crossed-out “Transcriptions” is now a key point of consideration. The interplay of text above and on the line provides clues about the writer’s intent and how to reflect this in the transcription.

Clarifying Visual Elements

I’m now fully immersed in the specific visual elements. I’m focusing on the relationship between “Reproductions” and the strikethrough “Transcriptions.” A careful review of the crop and the presence of the connecting “and” is my current focus. I’m looking for subtle cues to clarify the writer’s intent, and the layout of the words themselves, especially the placement of “and”, is now my prime directive.

Decoding Visual Structure

I’m now deciphering the visual structure in detail. The analysis of the phrase is leading me to focus on the ‘and’. I’ve been dissecting the relationship between “Reproductions” and the strikethrough “Transcriptions”. I’m meticulously examining the crop, and the connecting “and” is my prime focus. This process is crucial to accurately convey the writer’s intent. The precise placement of “and” is proving key in how I interpret the edits, which is leading me to clarify my representation method.

Representing the Edits

I’ve been meticulously examining the visual structure, leading me to focus on the interplay between the crossed-out text and the insertion. My analysis points to a clear primary correction: “Reproductions.” The tiny “and” between “Reproductions” and “Transcriptions” has emerged as a crucial detail. I’m focusing on preserving the visual presentation through markdown and am prioritizing an accurate representation of the writer’s changes.

Analyzing Additional Context

I’m now integrating the additional context into my analysis. The phrase seems to be a title or section heading, so I’ll need to consider how the changes affect the overall section. I am re-evaluating the “and” - it’s more clearly an insertion when seen in the larger context. This is clarifying the best representation. I am now looking at item 1 and item 2 to check and confirm my analysis.

\n\nI’m now integrating the broader context of items 1 and 2. The phrase seems to function as a heading for these two items. The addition of “and” seems less significant now, given the overall structure. I am still prioritizing accurate representation of the strikeout. Item 1 mentions “Originals”. Item 2 mentions “Reproductions and Transcriptions.” The heading is likely indicating that item 2 concerns both. So I’m leaning toward representing it as “Checking Reproductions and ~~Transcriptions~~ against Originals”.

Examining the New Items

I’m now fully immersed in examining the new items and their context. The phrase “of Texas A. and M. College : James Reid” is interesting, with the inserted “of” and the colon. Item 1 is the main focus, with an underlined heading and detailed content including a report. Item 2 seems shorter, with a diary fragment. I’m noting the capitalization of “State” and “College” in item 1.

Revisiting Mess Hall Details

I’m now diving into the specifics of the mess hall references. The handwriting clarity is a factor, but the context of “telephones,” “chapel exercises,” and “mess-fights” provides valuable clues. I’m focusing on “mess-fights” and its precise representation. Is it hyphenated or not? The “in College Mess Hall” phrase clarifies the location’s importance.

Prioritizing Textual Accuracy

I’m now fully immersed in resolving the mess hall details. I’m prioritizing accuracy in representing “mess-fights” and its variations in the manuscript. The visual cues are leading me to consider hyphenation. I’m checking the surrounding words and content for further clues. I’m focusing on “in College Mess Hall” to clarify the location. My primary goal is to provide an accurate transcription with clear presentation.

Decoding the Reid Details

My focus is now on the name “James Reid” and the surrounding text. The “Reid” appears clear and matches previous analyses. I’ve re-examined the dotted “i” and closed “e” in “Reid”. Also, I am now focusing on any peculiarities in “A. and M. College”. The insertion of “of” with the caret is clear. The “Wukly” in “Weekly Brazos Pilot” will be clarified with context.

Clarifying “Cadets” and Details

I am now focusing on refining the transcript, particularly “cadets,” and clarifying capitalization. The cursive-induced spelling variations led me to choose standard spellings for both “cadets” and “officers.” I’ve verified the “telephones” and “exercises” based on context. I’m prioritizing accuracy in representing the mess hall details and capitalization. The “mess-fights” is confirmed. Now considering punctuation.

Refining the Strikeout

I’m now reconsidering the strikeout’s intent. While it’s through “Transcriptions,” the small “and” above it complicates the visual. I’m leaning towards representing this as “Checking Reproductions and ~~Transcriptions~~” due to the placement of the “and”. The strikeout remains visually dominant but the small “and” suggests a possible correction of the original text, and I need to consider the intent.

Revising Representation Strategy

I’m now revising the representation strategy to align with the visual structure. The strikeout visually removes “Transcriptions” but the “and” suggests that this is now combined with “Reproductions.” I’m now leaning towards using a standard strikethrough for “Transcriptions” with the addition of “and” before “Transcriptions” as in: “Checking Reproductions and ~~Transcriptions~~ against Originals”. This seems to most accurately represent the edit’s intent. The line spacing is now the next focus.

Refining the Transcription

I’m now fully immersed in the nuances of the transcription. I’m focusing on consistency in handling abbreviations and formatting. The “of” is being transcribed consistently now. I’m prioritizing accurate representation of the writer’s quirks, such as the “u” shaped “ee” and the presence or absence of a hyphen in “mess-fights”. The line breaks will be preserved. I’m now verifying the “cadets” and “officers” spelling.

Representing Formatting Fidelity

I’m now fully immersed in the formatting requirements. I’m focusing on the “Weekly Brazos Pilot” issue. Since the prompt emphasizes preserving original formatting, and underlining isn’t directly supported in markdown, I’ll transcribe the text exactly as it appears. I’m prioritizing accuracy. I will not add italics because underlining is the original formatting. The other items are fine. I’m also ensuring that I maintain paragraph structure while rendering.

Prioritizing Transcription Accuracy

I’m now focusing on the transcription of “telephones,” “chapel exercises,” and “mess-fights.” I’ve confirmed their spellings based on visual cues and contextual clues. I’m prioritizing accuracy in representing these terms, and I will maintain the hyphen in “mess-fights”. The line breaks will be preserved. I’m double-checking each word to be exact.

Confirming Formatting Accuracy

I’m now comparing the final transcription against the image for formatting accuracy. I’m double-checking the indentation, capitalization, and punctuation based on the formatting requirements. I’m verifying the placement of the strikeout and “and” in the heading to match the image, ensuring that my markdown correctly reflects the visual layout. I’m confirming that I maintain all original line breaks.

Analyzing Transcription Details

I’m now diving into the finer points of the transcription. I’m focusing on the interpretation of “mess-fights” and its context. The addition of “of Texas A. and M. College : James Reid” requires a double-check on formatting. I’m paying close attention to “cadets,” “officers,” and “Weekly Brazos Pilot.” I am also refining the strikeout representation.

Generating the Final Transcript

My focus is now entirely on the final transcription. I’m prioritizing accuracy in representing the strikeout and added “and”. Line breaks will be preserved faithfully. I’m double-checking indentation for visual consistency. I’m focusing on “mess-fights” with the hyphen and the capitalization of titles like “College.” Now verifying the transcription and its formatting against the original.

Refining Strikeout Placement

I’m now clarifying the strikeout placement, focusing on the visual relationship. The “Reproductions” is above, not part of, the strikethrough. It appears “and” modifies “Reproductions.” I’m prioritizing accuracy in representing the original edit and the precise strike through the intended word.

Item 3: Report of Colonel Cole, Third
Administrator of the College on
canvassing the A. and M. Students
in August 1884.

Item 4: Recommendations of General
Gilmor Grunsboro, N.C. June 12, 1876,
for Col. James R. Cole to teach
English at A. and M. College

Item 5: Letter from Thomas S. Gathright
to Colonel Cole, August 27, 1878, on teaching
and schools, and on General Lewis(?), first
professor of English at Texas A. and M. College.

Item 6: Letter from Thomas S. Gathright
to Colonel Cole, Nov 4, 1879, telling
about the Governai?, the Board and
the reorganization of the College
less than a month before the
Gathright Faculty Collapse.

Item 7: Excerpts from Colonel Cali's
Autobiography

Decoding the Index

I’ve determined the image depicts a handwritten index or table of contents. The handwriting is the main challenge. It seems to be for some kind of document collection, and I’m focusing on deciphering individual words and phrases to understand its structure.

Interpreting the Text

I’ve been working on transcribing the index. I’ve successfully deciphered “Item 3,” which discusses a report on student canvassing. “Item 4” mentions a recommendation and a location. I’m focusing on “Gilmer” or “Kilmer” in that entry, and that date in the 1870’s. I’ve determined that the text is cursive. I’m noting any non-text markings such as the checkmark or a possible page number.

Analyzing Date and Details

I’m now focusing on the date in “Item 4” and the additional details for Items 5 and 6. I’ve re-examined the date, settling on “June 22” or “June 2”. Additionally, I’ve deciphered new key phrases: “for Col. James R. Cole to teach English at A. and M. College” for “Item 4”, “Letter from Thomas S. Gathright to Colonel Cole, Aug. 27, 1878, on teaching and schools, and on General Lewis, First Professor of English at Texas A. and M. College.” for Item 5, and “Letter from Thomas S. Gathright to Colonel Cole, Nov. 4, 1879, telling about the Governor the Board and the reorganization of the College.” for Item 6.

Deciphering the Details

I’ve been working on refining the transcription. Item 7 includes “Excerpts from Colonel Cole’s Autobiography.” Item 3 is now complete: “Report of Colonel Cole, Third Administrator of the College, on Canvassing for A. and M. Students in August 1884.” Also, Item 4 is now finalized. The name looks like “Gilmer” and the date is clear: “June 22, 1876.” I’ve also identified a crucial phrase within this item, “Gathright Faculty collapse.”

Refining the Transcription

I’m now revising my transcription, focusing on Item 4. I’ve re-examined the date, settling on “12” or “22”, but “12” makes more sense. “Gilmer” is correct. I’ve verified the phrasing: “for Col. James R. Cole to teach English at A. and M. College.” I am also noting the capitalization pattern in the index as I transcribe “Item 5,” focusing on “Letter from Thomas S. Gathright to Colonel Cole, Aug. 27, 1878, on teaching and schools, and on General Lewis, First professor of English at Texas A. and M. College.”

Analyzing Capitalization Patterns

I’m now zeroing in on the capitalization in the entries. I’ve re-examined Item 5: “Letter from Thomas S. Gathright to Colonel Cole, Aug. 27, 1878, on teaching and schools, and on General Lewis, first professor of English at Texas A. and M. College.” Based on letter style, “first” and “professor” appear lowercase. I also transcribed Item 6, which indicates the same capitalization pattern.

Transcribing Item 6 Details

I’m now focusing on “Item 6,” specifically the phrase “about the Governor the Board and”. I’ve determined “Governor” and “Board” are capitalized. I’ve also transcribed “the reorganization of the College.” Item 7 is now on my radar. It begins with “Excerpts from Colonel Cole’s”. Analyzing this reveals “Excerpts” and “Colonel” are capped. I am writing it as “Coles” or “Cole’s”.

Finalizing Cole and Dates

I’ve been re-analyzing the entries, focusing on resolving “Coles” vs “Cole’s” in Item 7. Further, I’ve confirmed that the date in Item 4 is “June 22”, due to the loop. Finally, I’ve confirmed “Autobiography”.

Clarifying Date Ambiguity

I’m now focusing on the date in Item 4, “June 12, 1876,” after re-evaluating the stroke. I’ve re-examined “1876” and “June 12,” comparing them to other ‘2’s in the document. I am also checking the history of James R. Cole, I can say “Greensboro N. C.”. I’ve re-confirmed Item 3: “Administrator of the College, on Canvassing for A. and M. Students in August 1884.” Also, Item 6, with “reorganization” with the ‘z’. I’m also now focusing on “Gathright Faculty collapse”.

Concluding the Analysis

I’ve completed my final review of the text, confirming “Coles” in Item 7 and the date as “June 12, 1876.” The formatting is now clear: numbered items act as headers, the text is on lined paper, and there’s hanging indentation. I am confident in the transcription’s accuracy.

Finalizing Transcription Accuracy

I’m revisiting the transcription for Item 5: “Letter from Thomas S. Gathright to Colonel Cole, Aug. 27, 1878, on teaching and schools, and on General Lewis, first professor of English at Texas A. and M. College.” I am also analyzing the “caret” in “Texas A. and M. College”. Item 6: “Letter from Thomas S. Gathright to Colonel Cole, Nov. 4, 1879, telling about the Governor the Board and the reorganization of the College.” Item 7: “Excerpts from Colonel Cole’s Autobiography.” My work is complete.

Verifying Cursive Conventions

I am now focusing on the consistent use of cursive shorthands. I’ve re-examined instances of “of” throughout the index. I confirmed that the “o” and “f” are linked in cursive. Also I’ve revisited the date in Item 4, confirming it as “June 12”. The “1” has a loop at the top, and the “2” has a loop at the bottom, which is standard cursive writing. This solidifies my understanding of the handwriting style.

Revising Capitalization Focus

I’m now focusing on the consistent use of capitalization within the transcription, especially in names and titles. For the moment, I have rechecked both the items 5 and 6 and verified the lower case usages. I’m focusing on “Nov. 4.” and ensuring proper punctuation is added throughout the document. Also, I’ve confirmed “of” is consistent with its cursive shorthand. The transcription, at this stage, seems solid.

Refining Cole’s Spelling

I’ve re-examined “Coles” in Item 7, and the cursive ‘s’ mirrors “Students” and “Lewis”. This strongly suggests “Coles” represents “Cole’s”, a possessive, despite the lack of an apostrophe. This also is found in the entry from “Colonel Cole’s Autobiography”. The handwriting style uses shorthand often. Thus, the transcription error is in fact not an error at all, the entry should be “Coles”.

Adjusting the Possessive

I’ve re-examined the possessive. The missing apostrophe is problematic, but I will transcribe “Coles” as it appears, consistent with the instructions and my goal of faithful transcription. The “2” at the top is clearly separate from the text. I am following the line breaks. I’m now certain about the final transcription.

Verifying Date Consistency

I’m now revisiting Item 4’s date. Comparing the “2” in “12” to other “2”s confirms it’s a “2”, not a “0.” I’m also confirming the capitalization of “A” and “M” in the various references to A. and M. College and re-reading the text. The transcription remains accurate at this stage.

Detailing Punctuation and Spelling

I’m now adding periods and commas, noting the consistent capitalization and abbreviations. I’m confirming that “Gilmer” is correct, based on historical context. I’ve double checked for periods at the end of each item, noting any missing ones. I’m noting the lack of a period at the end of Item 7. Finally, all the work is double checked.

Revising Output Formatting

I’m now implementing the Markdown formatting. I’m focusing on consistency in line breaks and indentation. I’ve double checked the use of periods, and the text. All the historical details look good. I’m checking the output, particularly line breaks and indentations.

\n\n

Item 3: Report of Colonel Cole, Third
Administrator of the College, on
Canvassing for A. and M. Students
in August 1884.
Item 4: Recommendation of General
Gilmer, Greensboro N. C. June 12, 1876,
for Col. James R. Cole to teach
English at A. and M. College.
I am now updating the output. I also am checking the markdown formatting.

Revising Date Interpretation

I’ve re-analyzed “Item 4,” specifically the date. Examining historical context and the ‘2’s, I’ve confirmed “June 22, 1876.” The loops align, and historical records support this date. I’m satisfied with this detail. I will revise the transcription to reflect “June 22.” I’ve also revised the output. The text and the historical analysis all look good.

I’ve finalized punctuation and capitalization, ensuring the transcription is accurate and consistent with the original document’s style. I’ve corrected the date from June 12 to June 22 and preserved line breaks and indentation per the instructions, adding missing periods. I’ve re-reviewed “A. and M.” and used periods in “N. C.”

Confirming the Details

I’ve re-examined “Item 5,” now transcribed it, then examined “Texas A. and M.” and added periods as requested. Also, “N.C.” I am satisfied with the current transcription. I will now re-examine the whole text, to ensure no errors were introduced. My analysis continues.

Refining Transcription Output

I’m now implementing the Markdown formatting. I’ve focused on ensuring the text output faithfully reflects the original document’s line breaks and indentation. After further verification, I am content with all the output, and I’ve added the missing periods where needed.

Analyzing Final Details

I’m now focusing on a final, close examination of the entire document to ensure the transcription is perfect. I’ve rechecked all the line breaks, indentation, and punctuation, particularly the periods. I’ve confirmed capitalization and abbreviations, including “A. and M.” and “N. C.” and “Coles”. The ‘o’ in the name is clearly open.

Validating Final Output

I’m making a final, detailed review of the entire transcription. I’ve rechecked every character and punctuation mark. The “G” in Gilmer is now confirmed. I also checked all line breaks and indentation. I’m satisfied that everything looks right.f

Item 8: Picture of Democratic
Members of 12th Legislature, who
chartered A. and M. April 17, 1871,
Colonel Cole being one of th thirty (
Original picture donated Archives
by Mrs. William Dratherage (?) (Mrs Cole)
the oldest daughter of Colonel Cole and
the mother of Mrs Paul Tayolor of Dallas).

Item 9: Sate(?) Certificate (Texas)
issued after examination in 24 subjects by superintendent
of Public Instruction, State of Texas, to
J.A. Cole, September 26, 1871. Grades
in all 24 subjects are shown to
be good and medium (4 and 3).

Decoding the Visuals

I’m deep into analyzing the visual request. My focus is on meticulous interpretation and accurate transcription of the image’s text. I’m prioritizing preserving formatting and structure, especially line breaks. Unclear sections are being flagged with [?] to maintain integrity. Accuracy is the name of the game, even if it means confronting challenging handwriting.

Unveiling the List

I’ve just moved beyond the initial image’s contents. I’ve identified the presence of a “3” at the top and begun dissecting Item 8. This section focuses on historical figures, specifically Democratic members from the 12th Legislature who chartered A. and M. in 1871. I’m noting the mention of “Colonel Cole” as an integral figure. The handwriting is cursive and poses some transcription challenges, especially with the crossed-out words.

Pinpointing the Connections

I’m now zeroing in on the family connections within the archival information. I’ve successfully transcribed the donation details: the original picture was donated to Archives by Mrs. William Deatherage (May Cole), the oldest daughter of Colonel Cole and the mother of Mrs. Paul Taylor, of Dallas. I’ve also begun examining the State Certificate for J.A. Cole. The handwriting is a mix of printed and cursive, demanding careful analysis. There’s an insertion above “examination,” and I’m deciphering abbreviations and crossed-out words.

Clarifying Cole’s Identity

I’m now focusing on James R. Cole. The initial “J” is clear. I’ve noted “in all 24 subjects are shown to be good and medium (4 and 3),” with “good” and “medium” underlined. I’m verifying specific transcriptions, like “Deatherage” and “Colonel Cole being one of the thirty”. I’m meticulously parsing the State Certificate, correcting my understanding, and the insertion of “after” into “examination.” I’m confident about “J. A. Cole.” Finally, I verified that medium is present, and correctly linked to the corresponding parentheses.

Resolving the Formatting

I’m now fully focused on finalizing the formatting, especially line breaks and indentation. I’m prioritizing the user’s need to preserve the original visual flow, so I’m paying very close attention to how each line visually starts and making sure to reflect any indentation in the output. I am incorporating superscript insertions within the text flow as best as possible while ensuring the information remains clear and readable.

Preserving the Layout

I’m now grappling with the precise representation of the text layout. The goal is to accurately reflect the original document, including line breaks and positioning of inserted words, while also ensuring readability. I’m focusing on the sentence with the “after” and “in 24 subjects” insertions above the words “examination” and “by”. My intention is to write the inserted words in the lines they physically appear within the transcript, though some formatting might be necessary.

Finalizing the Transcript

I’m now implementing the final formatting choices and transcription decisions. I have resolved the layout for Item 9’s tricky second line, opting for a clean “issued after examination in 24 subjects by Superintendent” for clarity. I’m focusing on ensuring consistent style across the output, so the user can use the transcript efficiently. The final draft is complete.

Confirming Final Details

My focus is now on the final polish of the transcript. I’ve been meticulous about capitalization, ensuring that proper nouns like “Democratic,” “Legislature,” and “Picture” are correctly rendered. I’m also double-checking punctuation and the overall formatting to ensure readability and accuracy. The priority is to deliver a flawless final draft for the user.

Validating Capitalization

I’m now focusing on the capitalization, meticulously verifying proper nouns throughout the transcript. I’ve ensured “A. and M,” “Colonel Cole,” “Archives,” “State Certificate,” and “Superintendent” are correctly capitalized. The words “good” and “medium” are underlined in the image but will be provided as plain text. I’ve verified the closing parenthesis in Item 8, Line 8, and the J in J. A. Cole. Also, I can confirm the “thirty{“ as a brace {.

Revising for Precision

I’m now refining the transcript based on final checks. I’ve re-examined Item 9’s second line, confirming “after examination in 24 subjects by Superintendent” is accurate. I’m double-checking “Members” in Item 8, line 2 and “oldest” in line 7. My focus is on achieving perfection.

Validating Members and Deatherage

I’ve just reviewed the transcription and can confirm “Members” in Item 8, line 2. Also, I’ve re-examined Item 8, line 6. I’ve successfully verified “Deatherage”. My overall focus is achieving a perfectly accurate and refined final output for the user.
